range of byte is -128~127,  and 0xff is 255, so 'endKey[i] < 0xff' is always true . @AlbumenJ

Looking at this issue from dubbo export/subscribe service, if (group, interface, version) is the same, only one ServiceBean can be registered, and if (group, interface, version) are different, multiple ones can be registered. 
Based on the above rules, we can use the three attributes (group, interface, version) to generate the id of the ServiceBean, instead of specifying the id, it will be easier to use.  For example: `ServiceBean:group/interface:version`

Hi, If you config zookeeper registry without  zookeeper-registry dependency, it will throw exception before AbstractRegistryFactory.getRegistry(URL url). You can debug the code at your local machine.

> > ServiceBean:group/interface:version
> 
> @kylixs Do id generation rules need to refer to url? I think this might be better；
> For Examaple: directServiceImpl&group=test&interface=org.apache.dubbo.samples.direct.api.DirectService&version=0.1

For current design for Dubbo, it is **NOT RECOMMENDED** for users to register or refer a interface while therer have another interface have the same three attributes (interfaceClass, group, version). For provider and consumer sides, this will cause potential problem. So I think `group/interface:version` just enough and we can make it fast fail when users act such forbidden action in provider side.

If it is a direct connection, there are two solutions:
1. The data implements serialization interface. Although the serialization type of provider and consumer are inconsistent, it does not affect data transmission.
2. The consumer side uses parameter to set the serialization type.

In some companies, there are short domains to simplify the full domain. So, the OPS team will set some rules to convert the short domain to IP address(if the domain doesn't exist, it will convert to the default IP address). Sometimes, the short domains is a string without separating with dots.

还有多少坑，从2.7.0踩到2.7.6了

> what does 'user-defined id' mean ? if duplicate bean id defined by user , an exception will be thrown

It is possible that the triples (group, interface, version) of the two ServiceBeans are the same, but the id is different. In this case, we should check and report an error.

In the bean definition parsing stage, checking the triples (group, interface, version) is more complicated but unreliable, **and it needs to be checked again when exporting the service.**

In addition, you can learn from the code of the ServiceBean name generated by @DubboReference annotation: org.apache.dubbo.config.spring.beans.factory.annotation.ServiceClassPostProcessor#generateServiceBeanName()
